issues.text: Whether the impugned orders dated November 8, 1955 and November 7, 1956 are valid under section 18A of the Industries (Development and Regulation) Act, 1951?

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the principal question for our consideration is the validity of the impugned orders made under that section. Learned counsel for the petitioners has attacked the two orders on the following grounds

issues.text: Whether the order dated November 8, 1955 fulfills the essential requirements of section 18A(1)(b), particularly whether the Central Government could form the opinion that the undertaking was being managed in a manner highly detrimental to public interest?

anchor.surface_text: 1 the order of November 8, 1955, is not a lawful order, as it does not fulfill one of the essential requirements of s. 18A of the Act under which it purports to have been made

issues.text: Whether section 18A authorises extension of the period of the order and whether the amending order dated November 7, 1956 complies with section 21 of the General Clauses Act?

anchor.surface_text: 2 even assuming that the order was a good order when it was made, s. 18A of the Act does not authorise an extension of the period during which the order is to remain in force, in the manner in which the extension was made on November 7, 1956, and such extension did not comply with one of the essential requirements of s. 21 of the General Clauses Act

issues.text: Whether the impugned orders are bona fide, given the appointment of the authorised controller who was allegedly mismanaging and party to disputes?

anchor.surface_text: 3 in any event, the order is not a bona fide order in that the Central Government appointed the very person who was mismanaging the undertaking, who was one of the parties to a pending dispute, and against whom an order of injunction had been passed by a Court of competent jurisdiction.

issues.text: Whether the conditions under sections 15 and 18A(1)(b) (investigation and detrimental management) relate to the period when management is vested in the owner prior to takeover?

anchor.surface_text: If these ss. 15, 16 and 18A, are read together, as they must be read, then it becomes at once clear that the condition as to the management of the industrial undertaking in a manner highly detrimental to the scheduled industry concerned or to public interest relates in its true scope and effect to a period when the management of the industrial undertaking is in the hands of its owner

issues.text: Whether petitioner No. 1 is legally competent to represent petitioner No. 2 (the company)?

anchor.surface_text: on behalf of the authorised Controller a preliminary objection was also taken that petitioner No. 1 was not legally competent to represent petitioner No. 2.

arguments.claim: The order dated November 8, 1955, is not a lawful order as it does not fulfill one of the essential requirements of s. 18A of the Act, specifically the opinion that the undertaking is being managed in a manner highly detrimental to public interest, because the authorised Controller was already in charge.
arguments.court_reasoning: Central Government had materials from ongoing disputes and investigations; distinction between functions of control under ESTA and full management takeover under s.18A; conditions relate to pre-takeover period.

arguments.claim: Even assuming the original order valid, s. 18A does not authorise extension of period in the manner done on November 7, 1956, and it did not comply with s. 21 General Clauses Act.

anchor.surface_text: 2 even assuming that the order was a good order when it was made, s. 18A of the Act does number authorise an extension of the period during which the order is to remain in force, in the manner in which the extension was made on November 7, 1956, and such extension did number companyply with one of the essential requirements of s. 21 of the General Clauses Act, No. X of 1897  and  3 in any event, the order is number a bonafide order in that the Central Government appointed the very person who was mismanaging the undertaking, who was one of the parties to a pending dispute, and against whom an order of injunction had been passed by a Court of companypetent jurisdiction. These three grounds we number propose to examine in the order in which we have set them out.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.21 GCA permits amendment in like manner and subject to like conditions; conditions (investigation and detrimental management) relate to owner-vested period and continued to be fulfilled.

arguments.claim: The impugned orders are not bona fide as Central Government appointed the person who was mismanaging, party to pending dispute, and against whom injunction issued.

anchor.surface_text: 3 in any event, the order is number a bonafide order in that the Central Government appointed the very person who was mismanaging the undertaking, who was one of the parties to a pending dispute, and against whom an order of injunction had been passed by a Court of companypetent jurisdiction.

arguments.court_reasoning: Test is whether for ulterior purpose other than statutory object; no materials to show so; selection rests with govt based on suitability and experience.

arguments.claim: Cannot challenge validity of s.18A due to Art.31B and Ninth Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the petitioners has frankly companyceded that in view of these amending provisions, he is number number in a position to challenge the validity of s. 18A of the Act.

arguments.claim: Petitioner No. 1 not legally competent to represent petitioner No. 2 (company).

anchor.surface_text: on behalf of the authorised Controller a preliminary objection was also taken that petitioner No. 1 was not legally competent to represent petitioner No. 2.

arguments.court_reasoning: Unnecessary to decide as petition dismissed on merits; pending in suit.

arguments.claim: Essential requirements of s.18A(1)(b) fulfilled: investigation under s.15 done, and opinion on detrimental management formed based on materials.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this argument as companyrect. We have already referred to the legal tussle which was going on between the parties with regard to the management of the industrial undertaking in question. The Central Government very rightly pointed out in their letter dated November 8, 1952, that the result of the differences between the parties was likely to be a stoppage of the mill and a fall in the production of sugar with companysequential detriment to the interests of the industry companycernedand the interests of a substantial body of companysumers, cane growers and mill workers.

arguments.claim: Distinction between functions of control under ESTA s.3(4) and takeover of management under IDRA s.18A.

anchor.surface_text: This distinction between exercising certain functions of companytrol, however, drastic the functions may be, on an order made under sub-s.  4  of s. 3 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act and the taking over of the management of the whole of an undertaking on an order under s. 18A of the Act is a real distinction which must be borne in mind, as it has a bearing on the argument advanced before us.

arguments.claim: Sections 15, 16, 18A must be read together; condition of detrimental management relates to period when vested in owner, before takeover.

anchor.surface_text: If these ss. 15, 16 and 18A, are read together, as they must be read, then it becomes at once clear that the condition as to the management of the industrial undertaking in a manner highly detrimental to the scheduled industry companycerned or to public interest relates in its true scope and effect to a period when the management of the industrial undertaking is in the hands of its owner

arguments.claim: Amending order valid under s.21 GCA as exercised in like manner and subject to like conditions of s.18A, which continued to exist.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the amending order is protected under s. 21 of the General Clauses Act read with sub-sec.  1  of s. 18A of the Act. Section 21 of the General Clauses Act says, inter alia, that the power to issue an order under any Central Act includes a power to amend the order but this power is subject to a very important qualification and the qualification is companytained in the words exercisable in the like manner and subject to the like sanction and companyditions  if any .

arguments.claim: Proviso to s.18A(2) not applicable to this case (orders not for 5 years).

anchor.surface_text: There has been some argument before us with regard to the proviso to sub-s.  2  of s. 18A of the Act, which we have quoted in extensor in an earlier part of this judgment. That proviso, it is companytended by learned companynsel for the petitioners, refers only to an order which is initially made for a period of five years, or, alternatively, which companyes to an end on the expiry of a period of five years.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to decide as amendment valid under s.21.

arguments.claim: Strawboard case distinguished; no retrospective effect issue here.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that the principle of that decision has any application in the present case. But as already stated by us, the provision in s. 21 of, the General Clauses Act embodies a rule of companystruction, and the implied power of amendment therein embodied must be determined with reference to the companytext and subject-matter of the provisions of the principal statute.

arguments.claim: s.21 GCA conditions for amendment are not the jurisdictional pre-conditions for original order (like s.15 investigation, mismanagement opinion), but conditions the order is subject to (e.g., max 5 years).

anchor.surface_text: In my view, however, when s. 21 of the General Clauses Act makes the power to amend exercisable subject to the like companyditions as in the main Act, it does number companytemplate those companyditions upon the fulfillment of which the right to issue the order arises under the main Act. If this were so, the power of amendment companyferred by s. 21 would have been wholly redundant and unnecessary.

arguments.claim: Family disputes and withdrawals by Onkarmal led to mismanagement justifying govt action.

anchor.surface_text: According to the case of the authorised Controller, trouble arose between the members of the different branches of the family of Managing Agents sometime in 1950-51 when it came to light that Onkarmal Khetan had surreptitiously withdrawn large sums of money from the accounts of the various businesses in which the members of the Khetan family were interested as Managing Agents, and this led to certain suits being instituted against Onkarmal Khetan.

arguments.court_reasoning: Ongoing tussle provided basis for opinion on detrimental management.

arguments.claim: After takeover, management improved, but prior issues justified s.18A.

anchor.surface_text: I say that after the management was taken over by Shri Kedar Nath Khetan, the Government has reason to believe that the management has improved and has saved further deterioration.

arguments.court_reasoning: Irrelevant to pre-takeover opinion; crux was disputes causing detriment.

holdings.text: The order dated November 8, 1955, fulfills the essential requirements of section 18A(1)(b) as there was an investigation under section 15 and the Central Government formed the opinion that the undertaking was managed detrimentally based on materials from disputes, relating to the period before takeover.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this argument as correct. We have already referred to the legal tussle which was going on between the parties with regard to the management of the industrial undertaking in question. The Central Government very rightly pointed out in their letter dated November 8, 1952, that the result of the differences between the parties was likely to be a stoppage of the mill and a fall in the production of sugar with consequential detriment to the interests of the industry concernedand the interests of a substantial body of consumers, cane growers and mill workers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected petitioner's claim by noting materials from ongoing family disputes and prior communications justified opinion; distinguished ESTA control from full s.18A takeover; conditions apply pre-takeover.

holdings.text: There is a real distinction between functions of control under ESTA s.3(4) and full management takeover under IDRA s.18A.

anchor.surface_text: This distinction between exercising certain functions of control, however, drastic the functions may be, on an order made under sub-s. 4 of s. 3 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act and the taking over of the management of the whole of an undertaking on an order under s. 18A of the Act is a real distinction which must be borne in mind, as it has a bearing on the argument advanced before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual comparison of statutory provisions; s.18B distinguishes effects; necessary for s.18A where control insufficient.

holdings.text: Sections 15, 16, and 18A must be read together; the condition of detrimental management relates to the period when management is vested in the owner prior to takeover.

anchor.surface_text: If these ss. 15, 16 and 18A, are read together, as they must be read, then it becomes at once clear that the condition as to the management of the industrial undertaking in a manner highly detrimental to the scheduled industry concerned or to public interest relates in its true scope and effect to a period when the management of the industrial undertaking is in the hands of its owner

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction avoids illogic post-takeover; links ss.15(b),16,18A(1)(b); opinion must precede vesting in controller.

holdings.text: The amending order dated November 7, 1956 is valid under s.21 General Clauses Act read with s.18A(1), as exercised in like manner and subject to like conditions (investigation and detrimental management during owner vesting), which continued to exist.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the amending order is protected under s. 21 of the General Clauses Act read with sub-sec. 1 of s. 18A of the Act. Section 21 of the General Clauses Act says, inter alia, that the power to issue an order under any Central Act includes a power to amend the order but this power is subject to a very important qualification and the qualification is contained in the words exercisable in the like manner and subject to the like sanction and conditions if any .

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.21 permits amendment subject to original conditions, interpreted via harmonious reading as pre-takeover facts persisting; no fresh fulfillment needed if management not reverted to owner.

holdings.text: The impugned orders are bona fide; appointment of authorised controller not for ulterior purpose.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the petitioners has contended that the impugned orders are not bona fide orders. He has submitted that the authorised Controller was one of the parties to the dispute which led to so much protracted litigation. He has pointed out that there was an order of injunction against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Test is ulterior purpose beyond statutory object; no evidence; govt discretion on suitability based on experience; disputed facts not resolved.

holdings.text: The orders dated November 8, 1955 and November 7, 1956 are both valid in law; no violation of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that the order made on November 8, 1955, and the amending order dated November 7, 1956, are both valid in law, and the petitioners have not made out any case of a violation of their fundamental right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative rejection of all three petitioner grounds via above analyses.

holdings.text: Preliminary objection on petitioner No.1's competence to represent company not decided on merits.

anchor.surface_text: In conclusion, it may be stated that on behalf of the authorised Controller a preliminary objection was also taken that petitioner No. 1 was not legally competent to represent petitioner No. 2. Having regard to our decision on merits, it is unnecessary to say anything more about this preliminary objection.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unnecessary as petition dismissed on merits; pending in suit.

holdings.text: Under s.21 GCA, 'like conditions' for amendment refer not to jurisdictional preconditions (s.15 investigation, mismanagement opinion) but to conditions the order is subject to (e.g., max 5 years duration).

anchor.surface_text: In my view, however, when s. 21 of the General Clauses Act makes the power to amend exercisable subject to the like conditions as in the main Act, it does not contemplate those conditions upon the fulfillment of which the right to issue the order arises under the main Act. If this were so, the power of amendment conferred by s. 21 would have been wholly redundant and unnecessary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate opinion by Sarkar J.; avoids redundancy; distinguishes jurisdictional vs ongoing order conditions; concurs on validity.

precedents.citation: Dwarkadas Shrinivas of Bombay v. The Sholapur Spinning Weaving Co. Ltd. 1954 S.C.R. 674
precedents.case_name: Dwarkadas Shrinivas v. Sholapur Spinning & Weaving Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Pronounced on Art. 31(2) of the Constitution with reference to the validity of the Sholapur Spinning and Weaving Company (Emergency Provisions) Ordinance 11 of 1950 and Act XXVIII of 1950
precedents.cited_holding: Held provisions invalid under Art. 31(2), leading to cancellation of authorised controller appointments

precedents.citation: Strawboard Manufacturing Co. v. Gutta Mill Workers Union 1953 S.C.R. 439
precedents.case_name: Strawboard Manufacturing Co. v. Gutta Mill Workers' Union
precedents.cited_proposition: Power to amend orders under s. 21 of General Clauses Act does not allow retrospective extension of time limits or where functus officio
precedents.cited_holding: State Government had no authority to extend time for award after expiry; s. 21 does not permit retrospective operation

outcome.relief_summary: Petition under Article 32 dismissed; impugned orders dated November 8, 1955 and November 7, 1956 held valid; no violation of fundamental rights; preliminary objection not decided on merits.

anchor.surface_text: In my view, however, when s. 21 of the General Clauses Act makes the power to amend exercisable subject to the like conditions as in the main Act, it does not contemplate those conditions upon the fulfillment of which the right to issue the order arises under the main Act. If this were so, the power of amendment conferred by s. 21 would have been wholly redundant and unnecessary.
